rules: Rule1: If artwork1 requires restoration, then artwork1 is valuable.
Rule2: Either the UV light test is positive for artwork1 or the infrared analysis is positive for artwork1.
Rule3: Under the condition that infrared analysis is positive for artwork1, treatment does not fail for artwork1.
Rule4: Whenever pigment is authentic in artwork1, treatment does not fail for artwork1.
Rule5: Either the collector's loan request is approved or artwork1 is valuable.
Rule6: If artwork1 is on a domestic loan, then the collector's loan request is not approved.
Rule7: Under the condition that artwork1 is on an international loan, the collector's loan request is not approved.
Rule8: If artwork1 is insured domestically, then artwork1 is on a domestic loan.
Rule9: If artwork2 requires restoration, then artwork1 is valuable.
Rule10: If artwork1 is insured internationally, then artwork1 is on an international loan.
Rule11: Provided that conservator1 is consulted as a restoration expert, then conservator1 recommends a restoration technique.
Rule12: Either conservator1 is consulted as a restoration expert, or artwork1 is on a private collection loan, or artwork1 is insured domestically, or artwork1 is insured internationally.
Rule13: If conservator1 prefers traditional methods, then, provided conservator1 is consulted as a restoration expert, conservator1 does not recommend a restoration technique.
Rule14: Either conservator1 prefers traditional methods or conservator1 prefers modern methods.
Rule15: If conservator1 prefers modern methods, then, whenever conservator1 is consulted as a restoration expert, conservator1 does not recommend a restoration technique.
Rule16: Whenever restoration phase 1 is complete for artwork1, restoration is completed for artwork1.
Rule17: Provided that restoration phase 2 is complete for artwork1, then either artwork1 requires restoration or artwork2 requires restoration.
Rule18: If surface cleaning is complete for artwork1, then restoration phase 1 is complete for artwork1.
Rule19: Either surface cleaning is complete for artwork1 or structural repairs are complete for artwork1.
Rule20: Under the condition that artwork1 has water damage, then artwork1 requires restoration.
Rule21: Provided that structural repairs are complete for artwork1, final inspection passes for artwork1.
Rule22: If varnish is applied to artwork1, then restoration phase 2 is complete for artwork1.
Rule23: Under the condition that final inspection passes for artwork1, varnish is applied to artwork1.
Rule24: If documentation is complete for artwork1, then restoration is not abandoned for artwork1.
Rule25: Whenever photography is complete for artwork1, restoration is not abandoned for artwork1.
Rule26: If preliminary assessment is done for artwork1, then a condition report is filed for artwork1.
Rule27: Provided that detailed analysis is done for artwork1, then either documentation is complete for artwork1 or photography is complete for artwork1.
Rule28: Either conservation plan is approved for artwork1, or preliminary assessment is done for artwork1, or detailed analysis is done for artwork1.
Rule29: If artwork2 has mold damage, then artwork2 requires restoration.
Rule30: Under the condition that material testing is controversial at the conservation lab, testing method is not approved by the conservation committee.
Rule31: Either material testing is controversial at the conservation lab, or, if restoration is not approved by the conservation committee, then alternative funding is not secured for artwork1.

Rule32: If research findings are significant in the conservation study, then either publication is submitted to the conservation journal, or, whenever peer review is completed for the conservation report, then, provided material testing is controversial at the conservation lab, testing method is approved by the conservation committee.

Rule33: If methodology is innovative in the conservation study, then either publication is submitted to the conservation journal, or, under the condition that peer review is completed for the conservation report, then, if material testing is controversial at the conservation lab, testing method is approved by the conservation committee.

Rule34: Either data is archived in the research database, or, if it is not the case that either research findings are significant in the conservation study or methodology is innovative in the conservation study, then study is not rejected by the conservation journal.
Rule35: Whenever ethical concerns are raised by the conservation ethics board, cultural significance is respected for artwork1.
Rule36: Under the condition that ethical concerns are raised by the conservation ethics board, treatment is not ethical for artwork1.
Rule37: Either ethical concerns are raised by the conservation ethics board or restoration is approved by the conservation committee.
Rule38: If restoration is approved by the conservation committee, then either artwork1 has water damage or artwork2 has mold damage.
Rule39: Provided that cultural significance is respected for artwork1, then treatment is ethical for artwork1.
Rule40: If environmental control is adequate in the gallery, then temperature is stable in the gallery.
Rule41: Either environmental control is adequate in the gallery or humidity is controlled in the gallery.
Rule42: Under the condition that humidity is controlled in the gallery, chemical treatment is not applied to artwork1.
Rule43: Provided that environmental issues are detected in the gallery, monitoring equipment is installed in the gallery.
Rule44: If preservation standards are met for artwork1, then monitoring equipment is not installed in the gallery.
Rule45: Whenever exhibition catalogue is published by the museum, conservation details are included in the catalogue.
Rule46: Under the condition that conservation details are included in the catalogue, artist biography is included in the catalogue.
Rule47: Provided that artist biography is included in the catalogue, provenance is documented in the catalogue.
Rule48: If provenance is documented in the catalogue, then, under the condition that artwork1 is not valuable, the museum schedules a public exhibition.
Rule49: If light exposure is limited in the gallery, then, whenever chemical treatment is applied to artwork1, chemical treatment is not safe for artwork1.
Rule50: Either light exposure is limited in the gallery or UV filters are installed in the gallery.

Rule51: If lighting plan is approved by the conservation committee, then, under the condition that UV filters are installed in the gallery, then, provided chemical treatment is applied to artwork1, chemical treatment is not safe for artwork1.
Rule52: Either lighting plan is approved by the conservation committee or emergency lighting is available in the gallery.
Rule53: Whenever fire suppression is enhanced in the gallery, security system is updated in the gallery.
Rule54: If alternative technique is suggested by conservator1, then conservator1 does not recommend a restoration technique.
Rule55: Provided that second opinion is sought from conservator2, then, if conservator1 is consulted as a restoration expert, conservator1 suggests an alternative technique.
Rule56: Whenever monitoring is sufficient for artwork1, immediate intervention is not needed for artwork1.
Rule57: Under the condition that regular inspection is scheduled for artwork1, environmental logs are maintained for artwork1.
Rule58: Provided that environmental logs are maintained for artwork1, preventive measures are implemented for artwork1.
Rule59: If insurance is verified for artwork1, then loan agreement is signed by the collector.
Rule60: Either insurance is verified for artwork1 or transport is arranged for artwork1.
Rule61: Whenever transport is arranged for artwork1, then either artwork1 is on a domestic loan or artwork1 is on an international loan.
Rule62: If lighting is appropriate in the gallery, then display requirements are met in the gallery.
Rule63: Under the condition that security is adequate in the gallery, the collector's loan request is not approved.
Rule64: Provided that artwork1 is exhibition ready, public viewing is approved for artwork1.
Rule65: Either artwork1 is exhibition ready or last minute checks are complete for artwork1.
Rule66: If last minute checks are complete for artwork1, then either lighting is appropriate in the gallery or security is adequate in the gallery.

Rule67: Either educational materials are prepared by the museum, or, if public viewing is approved for artwork1, then either lighting is appropriate in the gallery or security is adequate in the gallery.
Rule68: If positive review is received for the conservation work, then restoration criticism is not received by conservator1.
Rule69: Either positive review is received for the conservation work or professional recognition is received by conservator1.
Rule70: Whenever professional recognition is received by conservator1, industry presentation is made by conservator1.
Rule71: If chemical treatment is applied to artwork1, then chemical treatment is safe for artwork1.
Rule72: Either chemical treatment is applied to artwork1, or, if artwork1 is not valuable, then the museum schedules a public exhibition.
Rule73: If conservator1 is nominated for an award, then restoration criticism is not received by conservator1.
Rule74: Either domestic transport is secured for artwork1 or international transport is secured for artwork1.
Rule75: Whenever international transport is secured for artwork1, artwork1 is on an international loan.
Rule76: Either provenance gap is identified for artwork1, or, if historical research is completed for artwork1, then transport is not delayed for artwork1.
Rule77: If it is not the case that either artwork1 requires restoration or artwork2 requires restoration, then restoration is abandoned for artwork1.
Rule78: If it is not the case that if the UV light test is positive for artwork1, then pigment is authentic in artwork1, authentication is uncertain for artwork1.

Rule79: If it is not the case that if conservator1 is consulted as a restoration expert, then conservator1 does not recommend a restoration technique, restoration criticism is received by conservator1.

Rule80: If it is not the case that either research findings are significant in the conservation study or methodology is innovative in the conservation study, study is rejected by the conservation journal.
Rule81: If it is not the case that if temperature is stable in the gallery, then chemical treatment is not applied to artwork1, environmental issues are detected in the gallery.

Rule82: If it is not the case that if emergency lighting is available in the gallery, then, under the condition that UV filters are installed in the gallery, then, provided chemical treatment is applied to artwork1, chemical treatment is not safe for artwork1, fire suppression is enhanced in the gallery.

Rule83: If it is not the case that if condition is stable for artwork1, then either artwork1 is insured domestically or artwork1 is insured internationally, immediate intervention is needed for artwork1.
Rule84: If it is not the case that if chemical treatment is applied to artwork1, then chemical treatment is not safe for artwork1, treatment fails for artwork1.
Rule85: If it is not the case that if industry presentation is made by conservator1, then conservator1 is nominated for an award, controversy arises over the conservation method.
Rule86: If it is not the case that if industry presentation is made by conservator1, then conservator1 is nominated for an award, controversy does not arise over the conservation method.
Rule87: If it is not the case that if domestic transport is secured for artwork1, then artwork1 is on a domestic loan, transport is delayed for artwork1.

Rule88: If it is not the case that if it is not the case that if condition is stable for artwork1, then either artwork1 is insured domestically or artwork1 is insured internationally, then monitoring is sufficient for artwork1, regular inspection is scheduled for artwork1.
Rule89: If it is not the case that if restoration is not approved by the conservation committee, then budget is allocated to the conservation department, appeal is filed by the artist's estate.
Rule90: If it is not the case that if restoration is not approved by the conservation committee, then budget is allocated to the conservation department, appeal is not filed by the artist's estate.
Rule91: If restoration is not approved by the conservation committee, then alternative funding is secured for artwork1.
Rule92: If restoration is not approved by the conservation committee, then budget is not allocated to the conservation department.
Rule93: If preservation standards are not met for artwork1, then special storage is required for artwork1.
facts: Fact1: Peer review is completed for the conservation report.
Fact2: Exhibition catalogue is published by the museum.
Fact3: Second opinion is sought from conservator2.
Fact4: Condition is stable for artwork1.
Fact5: Historical research is completed for artwork1.
Fact6: Authentication is not uncertain for artwork1.
Fact7: Artwork1 is not on a private collection loan.
Fact8: Restoration is not completed for artwork1.
Fact9: A condition report is not filed for artwork1.
Fact10: Conservation plan is not approved for artwork1.
Fact11: Publication is not submitted to the conservation journal.
Fact12: Data is not archived in the research database.
Fact13: Special storage is not required for artwork1.
Fact14: Security system is not updated in the gallery.
Fact15: Preventive measures are not implemented for artwork1.
Fact16: Loan agreement is not signed by the collector.
Fact17: The museum does not schedule a public exhibition.
Fact18: Display requirements are not met in the gallery.
Fact19: Educational materials are not prepared by the museum.
Fact20: Provenance gap is not identified for artwork1.
